_source.metadescription: Prostate cancer is amalignant tumour of the prostate. Almost all cancers of the prostate (95%) are adenocarcinomas.

title: Prostate cancer
content: Prostate <mark>cancer</mark> is a malignant tumour of the prostate. Almost all <mark>cancers</mark> of the prostate (95%) are adenocarcinomas. Prostate <mark>cancer</mark> is multifocal — the
differ greatly in growth rate and ability to metastasize. Most prostate <mark>cancers</mark> are indolent and grow slowly — a minority are aggressive and invade local
Localized prostate <mark>cancer</mark> usually develops in the outer zone of the prostate, where it seldom causes symptoms. Locally advanced prostate <mark>cancer</mark> extends beyond
Metastatic prostate <mark>cancer</mark> most frequently affects the bones, where it causes pain and fragility fractures.  About 26% of all new cases of <mark>cancer</mark> in men are prostate

prostate <mark>cancer</mark> — it is the most common type of <mark>cancer</mark> in men. Prostate <mark>cancer</mark> is the second most common cause of <mark>cancer</mark> death in males in the UK (after

title: Ovarian cancer

cell, and squamous tumours. Non-epithelial <mark>cancers</mark> account for approximately 10% of primary ovarian <mark>cancers</mark> and include germ cell tumours, ovarian carcinosarcoma
the ovary, most notably from <mark>cancers</mark> of the endometrium, breast, gastrointestinal tract, and cervix (rare). Ovarian <mark>cancer</mark> may spread to intraperitoneal
ovarian <mark>cancer</mark> is about 1 in 52. The risk of ovarian <mark>cancer</mark> is increased by factors such as increasing age, family history of ovarian or breast <mark>cancer</mark>, gene
gene mutation, and endometriosis. The risk of ovarian <mark>cancer</mark> is reduced by factors such as an increasing number of pregnancies, breastfeeding, and the use

title: Cervical cancer and HPV

_source.metadescription: A family history of breast cancer is one of the strongest risk factors for developing breast cancer, increasing with the number of affected relatives.
_source.title: Breast cancer - managing FH

title: Breast cancer - managing FH
content: A family history of breast <mark>cancer</mark> is a strong risk factor for developing the disease. The risk increases with the number of relatives affected and the
age of diagnosis the greater the risk), and is modified by other breast <mark>cancer</mark> risk factors, including age at menopause, parity, oral contraception, hormone
therapy (HRT), and breastfeeding.  People without a personal history of breast <mark>cancer</mark> can be managed in primary care if they have only one first-degree relative
with breast <mark>cancer</mark> when over 40 years of age, provided that none of the following are present in the family history:Bilateral breast <mark>cancer.</mark> Male breast
breast <mark>cancer.</mark> Ovarian <mark>cancer.</mark> Jewish ancestry. Sarcoma in a relative younger than 45 years of age. Glioma or childhood adrenal cortical carcinomas. Complicated

title: Urological cancers - recognition and referral
content: Prostate <mark>cancer</mark> â over 41,000 new prostate <mark>cancers</mark> are diagnosed each year in the UK. A full time GP will usually diagnose one new person with prostate
prostate <mark>cancer</mark> each year. The 5 year survival is approximately 80%. Refer men using a suspected <mark>cancer</mark> pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
weeks) for prostate <mark>cancer</mark> if their prostate feels malignant on digital rectal examination. Consider a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test and digital rectal
rectal examination to assess for prostate <mark>cancer</mark> in men with:Any lower urinary tract symptoms, such as nocturia, urinary frequency, hesitancy, urgency or
haematuria. Refer men using a suspected <mark>cancer</mark> pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) for prostate <mark>cancer</mark> if their PSA levels are above the age-specific
